subject: Public Speaking
title: Mind Reading: Assuming Audience Judgment
description: One-minute skill: Mind Reading: Assuming Audience Judgment.

hook.text: You see someone in the audience frown and think: They hate my presentation. In reality, they're just tired.

buildup.text: Mind reading is the cognitive distortion of assuming you know what others are thinking â€” usually the worst.

discovery.text: Studies show speakers consistently overestimate negative audience reactions and underestimate positive ones.

twist.text: Audiences are generally rooting for speakers to succeed. A struggling speaker makes everyone uncomfortable.

climax.text: You can't read minds. The frown might be gas, boredom, or concentration. You'll never know â€” and it doesn't matter.

punchline.text: Stop reading minds. You're always wrong anyway.

quiz.question: What do studies show about speakers reading audience reactions?
options: They overestimate negative reactions and underestimate positive ones
They don't notice reactions at all
